ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Standard network XML dialect.
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, I do not shorten my tag names.  I keep them verbose.  As I mentioned in my previous message, I use compression to make the cost essentially

------=_NextPart_000_0024_01C3F856.64C824E0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Colin,

I do not shorten my tag names.  I keep them verbose.  As I mentione=
d in my previous message, I use compression to make the cost essentially in=
significant.  Later, if I have a need for uncompressed XML files and have t=
o think about that cost, I will just use XSL to then make the tags as "effi=
cient" as is needed.  At that point though, I am expecting the need for the=
 tags to remain human interpretable as having been significantly de-priorit=
ized and will likely resort to single character names and such.  It is very=
 similar to how obsfucators in interpreted languages have a tendency to wor=
k to make the code execute more efficiently.

Again, just playing my mantra=
 of repeating what Knuth said, "In software design and development, prematu=
re efficiency is the root of all evil."  :^)


Jim


  ----- Original Messa=
ge ----- 
  From: Colin Green 
  To: neat@yahoogroups.com 
  Sent: Saturday=
, February 21, 2004 8:31 AM
  Subject: Re: [neat] Standard network XML dial=
ect.


  Derek James wrote:

  >--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrot=
e:
  >  
  >
  >>Has anyone considered using XML for storing NN
  >>definit=
ions? 
  >>    
  >>
  >
  >Why...yes. :)
  >
  >  
  >
  ok, that's a good=
 start :) ...

  >Our Java implementation persists chromosomes in XML. 
  >=
Here's an example of a generational champion from a
  >successful XOR run:
=
  >
  ><chromosome id=3D"2853" primary-parent-id=3D"2763">
  ><neuron id=3D=
"0" type=3D"IN"/>
  >[...]
  ><neuron id=3D"2" type=3D"IN"/>
  ><neuron id=
=3D"3" type=3D"OUT"/>
  ><connection id=3D"4" src-id=3D"0" dest-id=3D"3"
  =
>weight=3D"-1.3731676929130425"/>
  >[...]
  ></chromosome>
  >
  >It's pre=
tty self-explanatory.  This chromosome is a
  >mutated clone (it has a sing=
le parent).  Chromosomes
  >that result from crossover have a primary and
 =
 >secondary parent.
  >
  yup, very similar to what I came up with. Which b=
asically means all we 
  would really need to do is settle on trivial detai=
ls such as tag and 
  attribute names - I'll adopt yours since they seem en=
tirely 
  reasonable/straightforward. Perhaps some additional data at the h=
ead of 
  a file to indicate which implementation and code version the data=
 came 
  from and other stuff like that. Note that the XML I posted was pur=
ely a 
  NN definition - not a genome/chromosome. The distinction was neces=
sary 
  because I was using an indirect encoding.  I never got around to 
 =
 outputting genome XML but with NEAT being a direct encoding one XML 
  dia=
lect does both jobs.


  >We also use XML to persist information about runs=
, and
  >we use XSL style sheets to convert the XML into SVG
  >for display=
 purposes.
  >
  >  
  >
  As Joseph said - very clever :)  Looking forward=
 to seeing the output 
  from these.

  >>I only ask 
  >>as I work a lot w=
ith XML for my day job and it would
  >>seem sensible for 
  >>all the vari=
ous NEAT projects to have some kind of
  >>standard for 
  >>transfering da=
ta. 
  >>    
  >>
  >
  >Yes...I agree.  Hashing out some XML standards se=
ems
  >like an excellent use of this list. :)  Anybody got
  >any strong op=
inions on formatting issues?
  >
  >  
  >
  Not really. I personally try t=
o keep tag and attribute names as short as 
  possible since they get repea=
ted so much and therefore add to file size 
  bloat if they're to long. So =
e.g. instead of src-id I might have used 
  src. And I might have used the =
word genome instead of chromosome in this 
  case - since the two mean the =
same thing within the context of NEAT 
  AFAIK. These are pretty trivial/pe=
tty points though. Most schemas I see 
  these days define lower case tag/a=
ttribute names (e.g. xhtml / xforms 
  tags are all lower case) -  note tha=
t XML is case sensitive.

  Regarding what sort of data to store, my initia=
l instinct is to save the 
  entire current population both at intervals an=
d at the end of a run - 
  creating a population.xml file. Within that file=
 we would store a list 
  of <chromosome> tags and at the top some addition=
al data about the run, 
  in fact I imagine it would look something like...=


  >Here's an example of some of our run.xml:
  >
  ><run>
  ><parameters>=

  ><num_generations>10</num_generations>
  ><pop_size>10</pop_size>
  ><ne=
uron_mut_rate>0.02</neuron_mut_rate>
  ><connect_mut_rate>0.04</connect_mut=
_rate>
  ><weight_mut_rate>0.75</weight_mut_rate>
  ><survival_rate>0.1</su=
rvival_rate>
  ></parameters>
  ><generation id=3D"1">
  ><fitness>
  ><max=
>75</max>
  ><min>38</min>
  ><avg>55.0</avg>
  ></fitness>
  ><specie id=
=3D"0">
  ><count>2</count>
  ><chromosome id=3D"0" fitness=3D"48454710" />=

  ><chromosome id=3D"1" fitness=3D"51381215" />
  ></specie>
  >
  >  
  >=

  Great minds think alike eh ;) 

  Apart from my comments above about kee=
ping names short this is 
  essentially the dialect I had in mind. One triv=
ial point - I would move 
  the <count> tag to be an attribute within the <=
specie> tag.


  Colin.

    a.. To visit your=
 group on the web, go to:
    http://groups.yahoo.com/group/neat/
      
  =
  b.. To unsubscribe from this group, send an email to:
    neat-unsubscrib=
e@yahoogroups.com
      
    c.. Your use of Yahoo! Groups is subject to th=
e Yahoo! Terms of Service.
